Alhajri Investigation a Kakasaheb Y. Nandiwale Writing – review & editing Visualization Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization c Jadid E. Samad Writing – review & editing Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization c Steven M. Guinness Writing – review & editing Investigation Formal analysis c Luke T. Roling Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Visualization Investigation Formal analysis d Alan M. Allgeier Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Resources Project administration Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization a a Chemical and Petroleum Engineering and the Center for Environmentally Beneficial Catalysis University of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas USA Chemical and Petroleum Engineering and the Center for Environmentally Beneficial Catalysis University of Kansas Lawrence Kansas USA Chemical and Petroleum Engineering and the Center for Environmentally Beneficial Catalysis University of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas USA b Department of Chemistry, Hansraj College, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India Department of Chemistry, Hansraj College, University of Delhi Delhi 110007 India Department of Chemistry, Hansraj College, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India c Chemical Research and Development, Pfizer Worldwide Research and Development, Groton, Connecticut 06340, USA Chemical Research and Development, Pfizer Worldwide Research and Development Groton Connecticut 06340 USA Chemical Research and Development, Pfizer Worldwide Research and Development, Groton, Connecticut 06340, USA d Chemical and Biological Engineering Iowa State University, Ames, Iowa USA Chemical and Biological Engineering Iowa State University Ames Iowa USA Chemical and Biological Engineering Iowa State University, Ames, Iowa USA Insight into the thermodynamics of liquid phase adsorption of nitrogen-containing compounds, which may serve as catalyst poisons for Pd/C, is important for the optimization of such catalytic processes in pharmaceutical industry. Here, the adsorption behaviors of six nitrogenous adsorbates pyridine, 3-methylquinoline, 3-methylisoquinoline, 4-methylquinoline, Hünig's base, and dibutylamine were examined by means of the Langmuir adsorption isotherm model. Equilibrium adsorption constants (K) varied from 141L·mol⁻¹ for 3-methylquinoline with pKa = 5.17 to 2271L·mol⁻¹ for dibutylamine with pKa = 11.39, indicating a strong dependence of adsorption affinity on pKa. The monolayer binding capacity far surpassed the availability of active palladium sites implying that the support played a significant role in equilibrium adsorption. Indeed, computation of a sampling of adsorbate binding energies for Pd(111) showed no correlation to measured adsorption constants, while adsorbate binding energies for R-COOH sites on the support showed a notable correlation. On the other hand, in a comparison of 3-methylquinoline to ethyl di-isopropyl amine as potential poisons, the suppression of reaction rate for styrene hydrogenation was strongly correlated to the computed adsorbate binding energy for Pd(111) and not correlated to the equilibrium binding constant overall. This observation further supports the conclusion that R-COOH sites play a significant role in adsorption equilibrium but experimentally determined equilibrium binding constants (via the Langmuir adsorption model) are insufficient to provide insight into catalyst poisoning. Rather analysis of reaction rate perturbations are recommended as essential for both practical and scientific examination of the role of catalyst poisons. These results offer important information on the adsorption mechanisms of nitrogen-containing compounds on Pd/C catalysts, which can be used in the design of more efficient catalytic systems for pharmaceutical use. Graphical abstract Keywords Catalyst deactivation Langmuir adsorption Pd/C Hydrogenation Pharmaceutical catalysis Data availability Data are available on request 1 Introduction Thermodynamic modeling of adsorption plays a vital role in estimating adsorption mechanism (i.e., physisorption and chemisorption).[1] Adsorption of a solute (adsorbate) onto a solid (adsorbent) certainly provides insights into how a process is occurring.[2–5] Currently, this approach is widely used in cleaning or separating various kinds of impurities in several different systems, but it can also be extended to understanding the mechanism of deactivation of a catalytic material.[6] To extract such information from experimental data, it is necessary to relate equilibrium adsorption to thermodynamic parameters via an appropriate adsorption isotherm model, which may be derived from first-principles or purely empirical. Generating and fitting equilibrium data have been discussed in detail recently.[7] Liquid-phase adsorption is a surface phenomenon in which entities of one or more components present within a liquid phase are concentrated onto the solid adsorbent surface.[8–11] Normally, this may occur due to the interactions of the adsorbate onto the surface of the adsorbents. It finds wide applications in industries dealing with water treatment, pharmaceuticals[12], and the petrochemicals industry[12], where control of the interaction at a molecular level accurately is indispensable. Certain parameters that determine the efficiency of such processes include properties of adsorbents, such as surface area, pore structure, and chemical composition; nature of adsorbate; and operational conditions involving temperature and pH. Among the most conventional models of adsorption, the Langmuir model interprets the adsorption of molecules onto a solid surface, considering only monolayer coverage with no interaction between adsorbed species. Irving Langmuir developed this model in 1918[13]; essentially, it was based on the premise that the sites of adsorption on the surface are uniform and that each site could hold only one molecule of adsorbate. According to Langmuir adsorption isotherm: (1) θ = q e q m = K C e 1 + K C e where, θ is fractional surface coverage K is equilibrium constant C e is the equilibrium-phase concentration of adsorbate qe is the quantity of adsorbate adsorbed in a single monolayer q m is the maximum adsorbate adsorbed. Common linearization of this equation includes[14]: (2) 1 q e = 1 K q m C e + 1 q m (3) C e q e = 1 Kq m + C e q m The N-containing heterocycles, adsorbates ( Fig. 1), are chosen according to their relevance in active pharmaceutical ingredients (API) synthesis and they should also have tendencies to bind the sites in a supported precious metal catalyst. 3-methylquinoline, 4-methylquinoline and 3-methylisoquinoline are used as intermediate, precursors or even as metal ligands for various kinds of drugs such as chloroquine and mefloquine.[15–17] Pyridine finds use as a precursor or moiety in various API syntheses and as a base.[18,19] Similarly, Hünig’s base and dibutylamine are used as reagents in many API synthesis steps.[20–24] In the present study, adsorption uptake at equilibrium was measured for N-containing heterocyclic adsorbates on the surface of a commercial Pd/C catalyst, having a high surface area at room temperature. These measurements were further fit to the Langmuir isotherm model to calculate the equilibrium adsorption constant, monolayer site density and Gibbs free energy for that N-containing compound. The analysis supports mechanistic studies of adsorption and reaction phenomena. 2 Materials and Methods 2.1 Materials The industrially available 10wt% Pd/C catalyst (Noblyst® P1261, Evonik) was used after pre-reduction. Anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF) was obtained in a 1L Sure/Seal™ bottle from Sigma-Aldrich to prevent moisture contamination; an inert atmosphere was maintained by purging with gas each time the bottle was accessed. 3-methylquinoline (99%), pyridine (99.8%, anhydrous), 3-methylisoquinoline (98%) and dibutylamine (99.5%) was obtained from Millipore-Sigma/Sigma-Aldrich, 4-methylquinoline (99%) was obtained from ThermoScientific Chemicals, and Hünig's base (99%) was obtained from TCI America™. After the reaction, the catalyst was separated using 0.2µm PTFE syringe filters. 2.2 Catalyst reduction Industrially available 10% Pd/C Noblyst® P1261 catalyst by Evonik was reduced in approximately 1g quantities in a 2.54cm horizontal quartz tube reduction apparatus after initially purging with 100 sccm N2 for 30minutes at room temperature. The sample was heated at 50° C under 100 sccm H2 for 60minutes and again flushed with N2 for 30minutes at room temperature. The furnace tube was sealed, then immediately moved to an inert atmosphere glovebox to collect the reduced/activated catalyst. 2.3 Adsorption experiments Adsorption experiments were conducted by charging 10mg of reduced Pd catalyst and 1mL of adsorbate solution to a 2mL vial with a stir bar in a glovebox. The vials were sealed and then stirred for 1 – 1.5h outside the glovebox to attain equilibrium at room temperature. The concentration of the supernatant was determined by gas chromatography (GC) analysis. Each experiment was conducted at least 2 times. 2.4 Screening Reaction A 1.5M solution of the model hydrogenation substrate (styrene) was prepared in anhydrous THF. Seven crimp-cap vials, each containing a magnetic stir bar, were prepared inside an inert atmosphere glovebox. To each vial, 10mg of the reduced 10wt% Pd/C catalyst was added, followed by 1mL of the prepared 1.5M substrate solution. The mass of each vial was recorded after each addition step. The sealed vials were then loaded into the reactor block. A pressure leak test was performed at 400psi for 30minutes. Following the leak test, the system was purged three times with nitrogen, then three times with hydrogen. Heating was initiated at the lowest possible pressure, and once its reached 35 °C, hydrogen pressure was increased to 150psig (~10bar), and stirring was initiated for 30minutes. After the reaction completion, the system was purged with nitrogen and allowed to cool to room temperature. The vials were subsequently removed, and the reaction mixtures were analyzed by GC. Calibration of model substrate was also performed using GC. 2.5 Gas Chromatography After the experiments, samples were first filtered using a 0.2µm PTFE filter to remove the catalyst. The concentrations of unknown adsorbates and styrene samples were then quantified using an Agilent 8890 GC equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and an autosampler. Quantification was performed using the calibration curve method. The instrument was fitted with an RTx-5 Amine capillary column (30m length, 0.25mm internal diameter, and 1 μm ﬁlm thickness) to ensure efficient separation and detection. The FID heater was set at 300 ºC. The flow of air was set at 400mL/min, H2 at 40mL/min and the makeup flow was done with UHP Helium at 45mL/min whereas the column flow rate of Helium was 1mL/min. 2.6 Data analysis The concentration after equilibrium adsorption, Ce (mol·L-1), was determined by GC and the quantity adsorbed on the surface was calculated. (4) q e = ( C i − C e ) m × V where Ci is the initial concentration before adsorption, and m is the mass of the adsorbent (reduced Pd/C). V is the volume of the adsorbate taken (in liters). The Langmuir adsorption isotherms for each adsorbate were plotted as the equilibrium loading (qe) as a function of the equilibrium adsorption concentration (Ce). Further 1/qe was plotted against 1/Ce and the data fit to Eq. 2 to determine the equilibrium binding constant, and the monolayer coverage, qm. The former was used to calculate the change in Gibbs free energy via Eq. 5 (5) ΔG = -RT(ln K) where R is universal gas constant, T is the absolute temperature. The adsorbate site density (qm-SSA), i.e., the monolayer coverage normalized to the BET specific surface area, was calculated by Eq. 6. The hypothetical Pd adsorbate site density (qm-Pd), i.e. the monolayer coverage normalized to Pd specific surface area was calculated by Eq. 7. Here, qm = monolayer coverage (mole/g), BET SSA = specific surface area by the BET method described below, Pd SSA = the specific surface area of exposed Pd measured by the method described below and NA = Avogadro’s number. The BET specific surface area (1426 m2/g) and the palladium specific surface area (3.8 m2/g) were taken as constants and measured, as described below. (6) adsorbate site density = q m − SSA = ( q m * N A ) BET SSA (7) hypothetical Pd adsorbate site density = q m − Pd = ( q m * N A ) Pd SSA 2.7 Catalyst Characterization The BET specific surface area of the Pd/C catalyst was measured from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms with a Micromeritics TriStar II Plus instrument. The samples were degassed at 80 °C for 7hours under vacuum before the analysis. [25] Nitrogen was adsorbed at -196 °C over a pressure range 0.05 to 0.25P/P0, where P0 is the saturation pressure at the measurement temperature and P is the equilibrated pressure. Ten data points were fit to the BET equation [26] to extract the monolayer surface area. CO chemisorption was performed using MicroActive for Autochem II 2920 version 6.01 using 0.0320g of catalyst. The process involved initially heating the catalyst in flowing N2 for 1hr to remove residual moisture. Temperature was then cooled to 50 °C and the flow was switched to 50 sccm of 10% H2/Ar for 0.5hr for pre-reduction. 50 sccm of He was subsequently flown for another 0.5hr to remove physisorbed hydrogen. The temperature was then lowered to 35 °C under He atmosphere before CO was injected in pulses and recording elution profiles with a thermal conductivity detector. Pd dispersion and active surface area were calculated assuming a Pd/CO stoichiometry of 1.0. 2.8 Density Functional Theory (DFT) Calculations DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP)[27,28]. Electron-ion interactions were calculated with projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials [29,30]using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [31]and the DFT-D3 method[32,33] to implement dispersion corrections. A kinetic energy cutoff of 400eV was used, and self-consistent energy calculations were converged to 10-4 eV. The Pd(111) surface was modeled with a 5 ×5 surface unit cell, 4 metal layers, and six equivalent layers of vacuum using an optimized lattice constant of 3.89Å. The lattice parameters of graphene (2.47Å) and graphane (2.54Å), chosen to represent two simple substrates for the acid site model, were optimized using at least 12Å of vacuum between layers. Acid sites were constructed on each carbon surface using a 5 ×5 surface unit cell (100C atoms) with a single carboxylic acid (-COOH) site placed on top of the C support (in the case of graphane, replacing one surface -H). Geometry optimizations were performed until forces on all atoms were less than 0.02eV/Å. All atoms were relaxed in all geometry optimizations, except for the bottom two layers of the Pd(111) slab, which were fixed at their bulk lattice positions. The most stable binding configurations found for each adsorbate and surface model are shown in Figure S11 with converged geometries (VASP POSCAR format) provided as supplementary files. Surface Brillouin zones were sampled with a gamma-centered 4 ×4 x 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh.[34] Dipole corrections were applied normal to the surface.[35] Binding energies ( BE s) were calculated as the difference in total energies of the adsorbed state ( E ads ) and the respective gas-phase molecule ( E gas ) and the clean surface ( E surf ), i.e., BE = E ads − E gas − E surf 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizing time for adsorption We began our study by characterizing the time required to reach equilibrium adsorption for the model substrate, 3-methylquinoline, which has the highest molecular weight among adsorbates evaluated. While this molecular weight is expected to provide the lowest diffusivity among the adsorbates, we acknowledge that all adsorbates are small molecules with similar diffusivities. Four adsorption measurements were conducted at 30, 60, 120, and 240min, each comprising 1ml of 0.05M adsorbate and 10mg of reduced Pd/C catalyst. There was no significant change in concentration among these measurements suggesting the system reached equilibrium even at 30minutes (Figure S1). For subsequent experiments a minimum of 60minutes was allocated to reach equilibrium for each substrate. 3.2 Adsorption Studies The adsorption studies were then carried out at multiple starting concentrations using 3-methylquinoline, pyridine, 3-methylisoquinoline, 4-methylquinoline and Hünig's base over reduced Pd/C catalyst. The adsorption isotherm data were plotted as the surface equilibrium loading (qe) against the equilibrium concentration (Ce) of adsorbate in solution. The data were further transformed and plotted as 1/qe versus 1/Ce and fit to Eq. 2 to determine K and qm. Fig. 2 presents representative data for 4-methylquinoline adsorption. Additional data sets are provided in the supporting information, and a summary, along with calculated ∆G values, is provided in Table 1. Analysis of the hypothetical Pd adsorbate site density reveals values 40 – 120 molecules / nm2 across the series of adsorbates tested. The trait is labeled hypothetical because it is calculated under the assumption that on Pd sites bind absorbates and the carbon sites are merely spectators. Under the assumption that the molecular footprint of these molecules falls in the range 0.16 – 0.50 nm2 per molecule, any hypothetical Pd adsorbate site density greater than 7 is unrealistic. Note that even the smallest molecule in the series (pyridine) is estimated to have an adsorption area of 0.23 nm2 per molecule from analysis of its crystal structure[36] suggesting a packing of 40 molecules/nm2 is not realistic. Accordingly, we conclude that the support contributes significantly to the adsorption equilibrium in all cases. The results also suggest that the catalyst surfaces present at least two types of sites (Pd and C) and given the complexity of carbon catalyst supports, a multiplicity of sites is likely.[37] Challenges of conducting liquid phase adsorption experiments have been extensively discussed in the literature.[38,39] An assumption of the Langmuir adsorption model is a uniform surface bearing a fixed number of energetically identical sites and it is acknowledged that the present system clearly presents non-uniformity. Still, the Langmuir adsorption model is widely applied to generate understanding of surface adsorption phenomena, while acknowledging its limitations.[38] We assess that this simple model provides sufficient fidelity and understanding of the experimental data to provide insights into catalytic behavior. The adsorbate site density (qm-SSA) was fairly insensitive to the identity of the adsorbate in this series, with values ranging 0.11 – 0.32 molecules/nm2, and always substantially less than the predicted packing for a close packed structure (c.f. pyridine packing from crystal structure data,[41] 4.34 molecules/nm2). Dibutylamine and Hünig's base are on the low end (0.11 and 0.17 molecules/nm2) and correspondingly have the largest molar volume and largest molecular footprint (see Supporting Information). Acid sites on the catalyst surface are expected to bind these nitrogenous bases and the data are consistent with some portion of the acid sites being close enough to each other that the molecular footprint of dibutylamine limits access to some of the sites. The potential for non-uniform distribution of acid sites is accommodated by the observation of low site density. It is acknowledged that pyridine also presents a low site density, an inconsistency in the proposed correlation (see supporting information). It is also notable that the solvent THF with its high concentration in these systems may dominate occupancy of weakly binding sites (physisorption). The low value of surface binding density observed for pyridine relative to the other aromatic amines is not fully understood but is certainly within the range of all adsorbates studied herein. The average equilibrium constants for adsorption for different adsorbates from Table 1, generally correlate with pKa values of the conjugate acids of the adsorbates. Hünig's base deviates from the apparent correlation which might be related to it being a tertiary amine whereby steric crowding negatively impacts Keq. The change in Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of binding necessarily shows a parallel correlation to the increase in pKa of the molecule. This trend may suggest that surface acid sites dominate the binding of adsorbates but leaves open the potential that Pd binding of aromatic rings and strong Lewis-bases would follow the same trend. In practice the data imply that, to some extent, the support may act as a poison trap and protecting the active metal sites. 3.3 Modeling of Adsorptive Interactions To better understand the competitive roles of acid sites and palladium sites in adsorption, a series of density functional theory (DFT) models were constructed to compute the binding energies (BEs) for representative bases: 3-methylquinoline, and Hünig's base, and for a representative hydrogenation substrate of pharmaceutical relevance, styrene. For the N-containing substrates the BEs on model acid sites, -COOH modified graphene and -COOH modified graphane, were similarly computed. The computations do not account for the role of solvation and are meant to provide relative insights into the adsorption events from modeling that is not resource intensive. It is noted that the BEs on Pd(111) for 3-methylquinoline and Hünig's base are not well correlated with the experimentally determined K values for adsorption, further supporting the above conclusion that palladium is not the only contributor to adsorption but that the carbon support plays a significant role. It is notable that the BE on Pd(111) for styrene is comparable to 3-methylquinoline, but stronger than Hünig's base, which should influence catalysis (vide infra). The observation is reminiscent of comparisons of nearly isostructural adsorbates: dibenzothiophene and fluorene, adsorbing to Pd/SiO2.[42] Furthermore, the binding energy of Hünig's base and 3-methylquinoline to the support acid sites are energetically sufficient to contribute to the overall adsorption equilibrium as proposed above. Indeed, the measured values are influenced, not only by the energetics computed at each site, but also biased for the relatively large population of carbon support acidic adsorption sites (expressed across 1426 m2/g), compared to Pd sites (comprising 3.8 m2/g). The somewhat stronger BE of Hünig's base, compared to 3-methylquinoline, for acid sites is correlated with its higher experimental K value and to a first approximation consistent with the van’t Hoff equation relationship. 3.4 Reactor Screening The performance of Pd/C in the presence of catalyst poisons / nitrogenous base adsorbates was evaluated using the representative substrate, styrene. Accordingly, styrene was treated with Pd/C (6.4% w/w relative to styrene) in THF solvent at 35 °C and 10bar H2 for 30minutes, optionally with 2mol% nitrogen-containing adsorbates, Fig. 3. Both pyridine and Hünig's base show no significant impact upon conversion, while the fused arene substrates 3-methylquinoline and 3-methylisoquinoline negatively impact conversion. The lack of correlation of conversion and adsorption equilibrium constant is initially intriguing but in light of the conclusion that adsorption is significantly influenced by the support, the data further underscore that adsorption isotherms are insufficient to draw conclusions about catalytic behaviour on supported metal catalysts. Indeed, Hünig's base has much higher affinity for the overall catalyst surface (Kav = 384 vs. 141 for 3-methylquinoline) but has no apparent impact on rate, while 3-methylquinoline has lower Kav but a higher BE for Pd(111) and greater suppression of reaction rate / conversion. It has been noted in the literature that the binding of aromatics to Pd can be sufficient to modify selectivity in catalytic reactions.[43] or inhibiting substrate binding.[42] Additionally the binding of quinolines to Pd(111) has been described as parallel to the surface by both experiments,[44] and DFT models,[45] consistent with our models (see supporting information), Pyridine’s adsorption mode has been described as dependent upon conditions and methods of modelling.[46,47] Some permutations suggesting adsorption via N-Pd bonding and others by aromatic pi system – Pd binding. Our data suggest that the fused ring substrates have higher palladium BE than the mono-arenes, styrene and pyridine, and the aliphatic amines. The reactivity trends are aligned with these BEs, rather than the experimentally determined K values. We acknowledge that the conversions in Fig. 3 were measured in a small volume screening reactor (1mL each) and a rigorous assessment validating the intrinsic kinetic regime has not been completed, nonetheless the rate suppression caused by 3-methylquinoline and 3-methylisoquinoline is clearly supported and aligned with the conclusions. 4 Conclusion The present study is a comprehensive thermodynamic examination of the liquid-phase adsorption of nitrogen compounds on Pd/C catalysts based on the Langmuir adsorption isotherm model. The findings suggest a positive relationship between adsorption affinity and pKa of the adsorbate conjugate acids, with equilibrium adsorption constants (K) ranging from 141L·mol⁻¹ for 3-methylquinoline (pKa = 5.17) to 2271L·mol⁻¹ for dibutylamine (pKa = 11.39). While the size of molecules does not strongly affect the adsorption site density, the data for the largest molecules tested (dibutylamine and Hünig's base) suggest some inaccessible sites remain at equilibrium, consistent with non-uniform spacing of adsorption sites. Some percent of the acid sites are in close proximity and inaccessible due to crowding. In addition, the unrealistically high values for the hypothetical Pd adsorbate site density calculations indicate adsorption is not limited to Pd but strongly influenced by the carbon support. The calculated Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) indicate that adsorption feasibility rises with pKa, from -11.6kJ·mol⁻¹ for 3-methylquinoline to -19.1kJ·mol⁻¹ for dibutylamine. Adsorbate binding energies calculated from DFT models further support that adsorption comprises both Pd and support binding sites. Comparison of equilibrium adsorption data to rates of styrene hydrogenation show poor correlations between conversion and K values. On the other hand, adsorbate binding energies for Pd(111) show a good correlation to reaction performance. While providing excellent insight into surface chemistry, laboratory-based adsorption studies are insufficient for addressing catalyst poisoning, and kinetic evaluations are critical. Glossary K Equilibrium adsorption constant θ fractional surface coverage GC Gas chromatography C e equilibrium-phase concentration of adsorbate qe quantity of adsorbate adsorbed in a single monolayer q m maximum adsorbate adsorbed ΔG Gibbs free energy DFT Density functional theory w/w weight by weight Kav Average Equilibrium adsorption constant BE Binding energy SSA Specific surface area THF Tetrahydrofuran

coredata.dc:description: Insight into the thermodynamics of liquid phase adsorption of nitrogen-containing compounds, which may serve as catalyst poisons for Pd/C, is important for the optimization of such catalytic processes in pharmaceutical industry. Here, the adsorption behaviors of six nitrogenous adsorbates pyridine, 3-methylquinoline, 3-methylisoquinoline, 4-methylquinoline, Hünig's base, and dibutylamine were examined by means of the Langmuir adsorption isotherm model. Equilibrium adsorption constants (K) varied from 141L·mol⁻¹ for 3-methylquinoline with pKa = 5.17 to 2271L·mol⁻¹ for dibutylamine with pKa = 11.39, indicating a strong dependence of adsorption affinity on pKa. The monolayer binding capacity far surpassed the availability of active palladium sites implying that the support played a significant role in equilibrium adsorption. Indeed, computation of a sampling of adsorbate binding energies for Pd(111) showed no correlation to measured adsorption constants, while adsorbate binding energies for R-COOH sites on the support showed a notable correlation. On the other hand, in a comparison of 3-methylquinoline to ethyl di-isopropyl amine as potential poisons, the suppression of reaction rate for styrene hydrogenation was strongly correlated to the computed adsorbate binding energy for Pd(111) and not correlated to the equilibrium binding constant overall. This observation further supports the conclusion that R-COOH sites play a significant role in adsorption equilibrium but experimentally determined equilibrium binding constants (via the Langmuir adsorption model) are insufficient to provide insight into catalyst poisoning. Rather analysis of reaction rate perturbations are recommended as essential for both practical and scientific examination of the role of catalyst poisons. These results offer important information on the adsorption mechanisms of nitrogen-containing compounds on Pd/C catalysts, which can be used in the design of more efficient catalytic systems for pharmaceutical use.

coredata.dc:title: Adsorption Studies of Pharmaceutical Feed Impurities on Pd/C Catalysts Fail to Predict Activity in Liquid Phase Hydrogenation
